m. the horse-sacrifice (a celebrated ceremony, the antiquity of which reaches back to the Vedic period ; the hymns RV. i, 162 and 163 [= VS. xxii seqq.], referring to it, are however of comparatively late origin ; in later times its efficacy was so exaggerated, that a hundred such sacrifices entitled the sacrificer to displace Indraindra from the dominion of Svargasvarga ; kings who engaged in it spent enormous sums in gifts to the Bra1hmansBrahmans ; it is said that the horse was sometimes not immolated, but kept bound during the ceremony) VS. xviii, 22; TS.; Ragh. &c, (cf. arkASvameD/a) 115,2 19961

As/uH ; p. m. s/at f. sat/I) to be, live, exist, be present ; to take place, happen ; to abide, dwell, stay ; to belong to (gen. or dat.) ; to fall to the share of. happen to any one (gen.) ; to be equal to (dat.) S3Br. xiv; Mn. xi, 85 ; to turn out, tend towards any result, prove (with dat.) ; to become Br2A1rUp. &c, (cf. Pa1n2. 5-4, 51-55) ; to be (i.e. used as copula, but not only with adj., but also with adv. [e.g. tUzRIm AsIt MBh. iii, 4041], and often with part., [e.g. perf. Pass. p. prasTitAH sma N. ; fut. p.p. hantavyo 'smi N. ; fut.p. especially with Pot., and only in S3Br., as y/adi dAsy/an-t-sy/At, if he should intend to give ] ; the pf. Asa helps to form the periphrastic perf., and asmi &c the fut.) ; ([cf. Gk. ἐσ-τί Lat. es-t ; Goth. is-t ; Lith. es-ti.])117,1 014821 20353
